required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Multi-elemental Imaging of Lung Tissues With LIBS (Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy)
clinical_study.official_title: Multi-elemental Imaging of Lung Tissues With LIBS (Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy) : a Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluate the feasibility of performing a multi-elemental imaging analysis of lung specimens from patients with ILDs, with an technology named LIBS (Laser Induced-Breakdown Spectroscopy)

detailed_description.textblock:
There is a major health problem due to the environmental and occupational related exposures to mineral particles, metals, and dust. The impact on health is considerable in terms of prevalence, morbidity and healthcare costs. Pathologists rarely report the presence of a possible mineral or metal-related etiology in a specimen by lack of available and convenient technology. Therefore, several respiratory diseases are considered idiopathic.
Interstitial lung disease (ILD), also known as diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD) is a group of lung diseases affecting the interstitium (the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs). In France, 15.000 new cases of ILD are diagnosed each year. ILD may be classified according to the cause. Idiopathic ILD are ILD of unknown causes. The most frequent idiopathic ILD are sarcoidosis and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).These two diseases are the core topic of the present study since they may relate to important mineral or metal exposure.
The overall goal of this MEDICO-LIBS study is to evaluate the feasibility of using a laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS)-based instrument to image(ie, identify, localize and possibly quantify) metals within selected human specimens with ILDs.

primary_outcome.measure: Generation of multi-elemental images in tissues with LIBS
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within a month after reception of the biopsy by the analytical laboratory
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of the feasibility of collecting and describing LIBS multi-elemental images of lung specimens originating from patients with ILDs

secondary_outcome.measure: Description of elemental distribution in the specimens
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within a month after reception of the biopsy by the analytical laboratory
secondary_outcome.description: Comprehensive chemical characterization of both endogenous and exogenous elements for each specimen

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within a month after reception of the biopsy by the analytical laboratory
secondary_outcome.description: Understanding of the elemental distribution according to the clinical data

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the elemental distributions with results of other mineralogical investigations
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within a month after reception of the biopsy by the analytical laboratory
secondary_outcome.description: Only for patients who previously benefited from other mineralogical investigations (eg, SEM-EDX), comparison of mineralogical analysis obtained with the elemental distributions obtained with LIBS

intervention.description: LIBS multi elemental analysis of the specimen

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient with ILD
- Patient informed, and agreed to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient opposed to participating in the study.
- Patient without available specimen.
- Patient under legal protection

facility.name: CHU de Lyon HCL - GH Sud

results_reference.citation: Busser B, Moncayo S, Trichard F, Bonneterre V, Pinel N, Pelascini F, Dugourd P, Coll JL, D'Incan M, Charles J, Motto-Ros V, Sancey L. Characterization of foreign materials in paraffin-embedded pathological specimens using in situ multi-elemental imaging with laser spectroscopy. Mod Pathol. 2018 Mar;31(3):378-384. doi: 10.1038/modpathol.2017.152. Epub 2017 Nov 17.
Busser et al., Coord Chem Rev, 2018, 358, p70
